Issues.Title: Tailwind doesnt allow forcing !important with selector in place
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

3.1.6

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

vite 3.0.3

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

16.14.10

**What browser are you using?**

Firefox 101/Chromium 103

**What operating system are you using?**

Fedora 36

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/2OCzJLtC9x

**Describe your issue**

Tailwind allows 2 modes for important application:
Mode 1 lets me go with !important on all styles
Mode 2 with just a selector.

However many common frameworks exist that share styles with tailwind and override them with !important if i only use a selector.
For these Tailwind would need to allow me to not only use the selector but also mark the generated styles as !important by default.

So important: '#selector', forceimportant: true
Or something similar.

Else i'd be forced to override each style bootstrap happens to share on an existing page with !p-2 or !px-2 - and hoping bootstrap doesnt add any more on updates.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Tailwind doesnt allow forcing !important with selector in place" (#8979)

Issues.Title: A11y issue : semantics on Lists being removed with Safari as list-style: none is a default.
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**
v3.1.6

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**
React v18.2.0

**What version of Node.js are you using?**
v16.14.2

**What browser are you using?**
Safari v15.5

**What operating system are you using?**
macOS Monterey v12.4

**Reproduction URL**
Create a basic React app with CRA for instance, add a list `<ul>` with a few elements. Launch VoiceOver and go through the page content to find the list. VoiceOver does not announce any list and just reads each `<li>` element text. 

**Describe your issue**
Because `list-style: none` is applied as default by Tailwind, semantics are removed as aknowledged by different people working on accessibility (check this post : https://www.scottohara.me/blog/2019/01/12/lists-and-safari.html).
I understand why native styles are removed as default (they are usually reset) and this is more a Safari issue. Yet, as tailwind reaches almost 3M downloads per week (https://www.npmjs.com/package/tailwindcss), this behaviour may have a significant impact. Of course, it's up to Safari developers to fix this on their side if they're willing to. Meanwhile, an alternative to default styles for lists should be provided, or at least something in the docs to notify tailwind users about this issue. 

One hack to restore semantics when `list-style: none` is applied : https://gerardkcohen.me/writing/2017/voiceover-list-style-type.html
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "A11y issue : semantics on Lists being removed with Safari as list-style: none is a default." (#8975)

Issues.Title: Buttons have cursor: pointer by default, but should not for accessibility reasons
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

3.1.6

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Vite 3.0.0 (rollup)

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

v16.13.0

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

https://stackblitz.com/edit/react-tailwind-qds1vc?file=index.js

**Describe your issue**

While it's common to give `<button>`s `cursor: pointer;`, this is an anti-pattern. The [CSS spec](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-3/#valdef-cursor-pointer) establishes that `cursor: pointer` indicates an element is a link.

[This article](https://medium.com/simple-human/buttons-shouldnt-have-a-hand-cursor-b11e99ca374b) has some additional justification for this. I understand many users will want to override this behavior back to the common misuse of `cursor: pointer;`, but Tailwind should be correct by default.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Buttons have cursor: pointer by default, but should not for accessibility reasons" (#8961)

Issues.Title: Don't use `cursor: pointer` for buttons by default
Issues.Body:
This is a pretty common expectation but as outlined in in #8961 isn't really right. We considered this a long time ago but it felt too against the grain at the time. These days though very UI-forward applications like [Linear](https://linear.app/) are using the default cursor for buttons and I think this trend will continue as more people become aware that `cursor: pointer` is meant for links.

Let's update our defaults here to help nudge people in this direction and make it more common. If people want to change this in their own apps, it's just a line or two of CSS to add to their projects.

Closed #8961.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Don't use `cursor: pointer` for buttons by default" (#8962)

Issues.Title: Auto-reload not triggered upon making a change to HTML or adding Tailwind classes (unless AlpineJS script is commented out)
Issues.Body:
<!---
Thanks for filing an issue 😄 ! Before you submit, please read the following:

Search open/closed issues before submitting since someone might have asked the same thing before!
-->

# 🐛 bug report: 

Auto-reload is not triggered upon making a change to HTML or adding Tailwind classes (unless AlpineJS script is commented out)

<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue here -->

Page doesn't auto-reload after applying changes to HTML or when adding Tailwind classes. I have to reload manually to get the changes to apply. However, when I comment out the CDN from AlpineJS, it works just fine.

## 🎛 Configuration (.babelrc, package.json, cli command)

<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what your babel configuration looks like -->

Here's what my package.json config looks like:

```
{
  "name": "kickoff",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "parcel src/index.html --open",
    "build": "parcel build src/index.html",
    "test": "npm run eslint && echo \"✅✅✅ All tests passed ✅✅✅\"",
    "eslint": "eslint --fix"
  },
  "repository": {
    "type": "git",
    "url": "git+https://github.com/nikoescobal/kickoff.git"
  },
  "keywords": [],
  "author": "",
  "license": "MIT",
  "bugs": {
    "url": "https://github.com/nikoescobal/kickoff/issues"
  },
  "homepage": "https://github.com/nikoescobal/kickoff#readme",
  "devDependencies": {
    "@babel/eslint-parser": "^7.18.9",
    "@parcel/css": "^1.12.0",
    "@parcel/transformer-sass": "^2.6.2",
    "eslint": "^8.20.0",
    "eslint-config-airbnb-base": "^15.0.0",
    "eslint-plugin-import": "^2.26.0",
    "postcss-cli": "^10.0.0", 
    "tailwindcss": "^3.1.6",
    "parcel": "^2.6.2"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "alpinejs": "^3.10.2"
  }
}

```

## 🤔 Expected Behavior

<!--- Tell us what should happen -->

Making to the HTML or adding Tailwind classes should automatically trigger an auto-reload from Parcel.

## 😯 Current Behavior

<!--- Tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->

<!--- If you are seeing an error, please include the full error message and stack trace -->

I have to manually reload for the HTML changes/Tailwind classes to apply. However, if I uncomment the AlpineJS CDN, it works just fine.

## 💁 Possible Solution

<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug -->

Commenting out the AlpineJS script makes the file work, but then this defeats the purpose of being able to quickly build with both AlpineJS and TailwindCSS, given that I'll have to comment and then uncomment the CDN each time I'll be adding new methods, etc.

## 🔦 Context

<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->

I'm trying to set up a template so I can easily start a project with Parcel, TailwindCSS, and AlpineJS configured. 

<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->

## 💻 Code Sample

<!-- Please provide a code repository, gist, code snippet, or sample files to reproduce the issue -->

[Link to the repo](https://github.com/nikoescobal/kickoff)

## 🌍 Your Environment

<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->

| Software         | Version(s) |
| ---------------- | ---------- |
| TailwindCSS | ^3.1.6
| Parcel           | ^2.6.2
| Node            | v16.16.0
| npm/Yarn     | 8.5.5
| Alpine           | ^3.10.2
| Operating System | MacOS Monterey v12.4

Issues.Title: Custom variant utilities sometimes incorrectly get prefixed
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** v3.1.6 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** Laravel Mix **What version of Node.js are you using?** v16.15.1 **What browser are you using?** Chrome **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** https://play.tailwindcss.com/crlyVAimAY **Describe your issue** First thing to mention, we use a `prefix` of `tw-`. We have created a custom variant called `lighthub`. This variant only gets applied when a parent element has the class `.tw-lighthub` applied e.g. ```html
Lorem ispum
``` The above example works absolutely fine, but we have just come across a situation that didn't work. ```html
Lorem ispum
``` In the above example, the `tw-space-y-6` was not being applied. When we looked at the generated CSS, we can see the following... ```css .tw-lighthub .tw-lighthub\:tw-space-y-6 > :not([hidden]) ~ :not([hidden]) { --tw-space-y-reverse: 0; margin-top: calc(1.5rem * calc(1 - var(--tw-space-y-reverse))); margin-bottom: calc(1.5rem * var(--tw-space-y-reverse)); } .tw-lighthub .lighthub\:tw-bg-slate-400 { --tw-bg-opacity: 1; background-color: rgb(148 163 184 / var(--tw-bg-opacity)); } ``` It seems that the `lighthub` variant is being incorrectly prefixed for the `tw-space-y-6` utility. This is what our `addVariant` plugin looks like. ```javascript plugins: [ plugin(function ({ addVariant, e }) { addVariant('lighthub', ({ modifySelectors, separator }) => { modifySelectors(({ className }) => { const element = e(`lighthub${separator}${className}`); return `.lighthub .${element}`; }); }); }) ], ```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Custom variant utilities sometimes incorrectly get prefixed" (#8906)

Issues.Title: Add `touch` and `no-touch` variants
Issues.Body:
Hi This PR adds `touch` and `no-touch` variants to detect if the device is touch-enabled. It uses [`(hover: hover) & (hover: none)`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media/hover), but I can change the media query to use [`(pointer: fine)` & `(pointer: coarse)`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media/pointer). ```html

Use your mouse wheel to zoom.

Use pinch to zoom.

``` Thanks
